description: First case of Coronavirus in London, the ninth in the UK.
Supermarkets ration essential food and household items in response to panic buying.
First recorded Death from Coronavirus in London
Prime Minister advises against unnecessary travel and activity
TfL closes 37 tube stations and announces drastic reduction to service levels
Prime Minister announces that all cafes, pubs, restaurants and indoor entertainment must close.
First national lockdown begins
Public Transport Patronage down 92% on tube and rail, 80% on buses. 30% of TfL staff self-isolating.
TfL trials middle-door boarding (no fare collection) following the death of 5 bus drivers
TfL Easter Message “Stay at Home, don’t travel, save lives”. Transport patronage drops 95% rail/tube, 85% bus
TfL implements middle-door boarding for all buses. 21 Transport workers have died so far.
Mayor of London Sadiq Khan notices a significant reduction in air pollution by around 40 per cent.
Five-level covid-alert system introduced, with England currently at stage four.
Outdoor activities and shopping reopens. Those unable to work from home are permitted to return to work. Government and TfL encourage use of face masks.
TfL increases service levels and reopens seven previously closed stations.
With screen barriers installed, TfL begins a phased reintroduction of front-door boarding and fare collection on 85 bus routes
The use of TfL Cycle Hire surges during lockdown, with its best weekend figure of 132,979 hires on 30-31 May.
Further easing of restrictions, with schools beginning to reopen. More outdoor activities are allowed.
New arrivals from overseas are required to quarantine at home for 14 days.
Support bubbles are introduced, allowing isolated individuals the ability to mix with another household.
Wearing a face covering becomes compulsory on Public Transport. Non-essential retail reopens.
Government lowers COVID-19 alert level from four to three.
Indoor activities and dining reopen. TfL running over 90% of tube and bus services. Rented e-scooters are now allowed on roads in the UK.
All buses now collecting fares with front-door boarding. Small increase in safe bus capacity.
Month-long “Eat Out to Help Out” scheme begins, with government subsidising meal cost at restaurants.
Requirement for wearing face coverings expanded to more indoor venues such as museums.
Two weeks later than originally planned, indoor activities including sports, performance and beauty services reopen.
Schools reopen. TfL runs extra bus services to meet demand with pupils encouraged to walk or cycle.
The “rule of six” comes into effect, limiting indoor and outdoor gatherings to six people.
Government raises COVID-19 alert level from three to four.
NHS Contact Tracing app launches. 10pm curfew placed on hospitality venues.
Government launches new three-tier restriction system, with London in the lowest tier.
Second National Lockdown
TfL launches a bidding process to select e-scooter rental operators for a 12-month trial in London, following the government permitting e-scooter rental in the UK.
Second National Lockdown ends, a revised version of the three tier system resumes. London is placed in the middle tier with most of the country.
TfL releases data showing that almost half of trips were made on foot or by bike between April and June.
London moved to tier 3 restrictions, preventing all indoor activities and gatherings of multiple households. Travel is strongly discouraged.

Three-tier system extended to a fourth tier, with London placed in the new highest tier. This tier’s rules are similar to November’s national lockdown. Christmas relaxation reduced to Christmas Day only.
Vaccinations begin.

Rest of the country joins London in a third National Lockdown, Covid-19 alert level raised to maximum of five. TfL affirms advice to not travel unless there is a “reasonable excuse”, 10% of TfL staff are self-isolating.
Mayor of London declares a Major Incident, with the Office of National Statistics estimating that one in 30 Londoners have Covid-19
TfL publishes new Cycle Count data showing that cycling increased by 7% in inner London and 22% in outer London.
The Government’s hotel quarantine program begins, with new arrivals from red-list countries required to pay for their mandatory 10 stay.
Imperial College London’s Reach study finds that COVID-19 infections have dropped by 80% in London since the beginning of the third lockdown.
Government lowers COVID-19 alert level from the maximum of five to four.
Schools and Colleges reopen, TfL provides extra buses and urges students to walk or cycle to school.
Stay at home order ends, two households are able to mix outdoors, sport facilities reopen. TfL continues to recommend people limit travel.
Non-essential retail, outdoor hospitality and some indoor activities reopen, TfL advises people to travel in off-peak times while it continues to maintain service cleanliness
Wembley Stadium hosts the FA Cup semi-final with 4,000 spectators, a pilot of a government program for safely holding large events.
Government lowers COVID-19 alert level from four to three.
Restrictions are further eased, with all indoor hospitality allowed to reopen. TfL revises capacity limits on buses, doubling the amount of people they can hold as it continues to run a full service.
TfL chooses three companies to provide rental e-scooters for a trial in several boroughs from 7 June.
